awd_titl_txt: Can tight linkage mimic pleiotropy during speciation?  The effects and evolution of recombination between mating and local-adaptation loci.
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop mathematical models that examine the evolutionary processes by which one species splits into two: speciation. It has been thought that the genes that are uniquely important in promoting speciation are those that have dual functions that both allow the survival of individuals in their environment and allow individuals to attract mates of the same species. However, such genes appear to be quite rare. Some evidence exists that close physical proximity on a chromosome of genes involved in these two functions (survival and mate attraction) may also be very effective in allowing populations of recently diverged species that then come in contact to maintain their identity. The research will further explore the conditions under which close proximity of these genes mimics the properties of one gene with two functions, both in the maintenance of species and in the generation of new species. The researchers will also develop and distribute curriculum materials for teaching biology majors how to approach questions using mathematical modeling. 

The project will address these questions through mathematical modeling using a combination of population-genetic and individual-based approaches. These models will first address whether tight linkage of genes under ecologically divergent selection and genes that are the targets of assortative mating can mimic a single pleiotropic gene with these functions, concentrating on the evolution of choosiness during assortative mating.  Next, the researchers will address whether traits under divergent selection and those used in mate choice will evolve to co-localize during the process of speciation with gene flow. This will be explored both by assessing the evolution of modifiers of recombination rate and by examining the fate of standing variation of genes when ecological and mating traits are controlled by many loci across the genome.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Speciation, the process by which one species changes over evolutionary time into two distinct species that are no longer exchanging genetic material, involves the action of several classes of genes with different functions. These include genes that are important for ecological adaptation, where different genetic variants that allow adaptation to different environments become established in each species, and genes that code for characteristics that are important targets of mate choice, whereby different mating cues become characteristic of each species. It has long been thought that speciation is facilitated the most when one gene shares both of these two functions, that is, it is “pleiotropic”.

In the work from this proposal, the PI showed that tight physical linkage between ecological and mating genes, that is, having separate genes with each of these functions sitting in close physical proximity on a chromosome, closely approximates the effectiveness of pleiotropic genes in driving speciation. Contrary to prior belief, however, evolutionary divergence in the mating genes drives divergence in the genes with ecological function, rather than vice versa. Moreover, genes with tight physical linkage can drive the evolution of individuals being choosier in accepting potential mates than can pleiotropy – another important component of the evolution of barriers to gene exchange between species.  

The studies funded by this grant have also demonstrated two different mechanisms by which tighter physical linkage will evolve between ecological and mating loci from a situation when the genes are further apart on a chromosome (or even on different chromosomes). First genetic modifiers that decrease recombination between ecological and mating loci will tend to evolve in a population. Second, tight physical linkage can evolve from a sieve-like mechanism; ecological and mating loci with tighter physical linkage tend to diverge between populations in the process of speciating, while variation is lost across both populations at more loosely linked loci that are further apart.

Together, the projects funded by this grant have thus provided a much richer understanding of the relationship between the genes involved in keeping species apart, by contradicting the prior dogma that pleiotropy provided the ideal conditions for speciation.

The broader impacts conducted under this award include several efforts.  The PI has a textbook under contract with Princeton University Press whose function is to introduce biology students to the approach of mathematical modeling for addressing ecological and evolutionary questions. Ten chapters out of the twelve that will comprise this book were drafted during the tenure of the grant. One postdoc, four graduate students, and three undergraduates were trained in mathematical modeling techniques, completing a wide variety of research projects. The results of the research in the proposal were disseminated in a number of publications as well as presented at universities in invited seminars and at national meetings.
